title: Does Tempo Matter in The Big Ten?
text:
To start I loaded the required libraries for this project.


Code
suppressMessages(library(tidyverse))
suppressMessages(library(scales))


Then, I’ll load in both libraries.


Code
suppressMessages(twentyfour_plays <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs24.csv"))
suppressMessages(twentyfive_plays <- read_csv("https://thescoop.org/sports-data-files/footballlogs25.csv"))


Then I had to isolate our Big Ten teams, and add a column that has the total plays for each team in the conference.


Code
twentyfour_btn <- twentyfour_plays |> filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference") |>  group_by(TeamFull) |> summarise(total_plays = sum(TotalPlays), avg_plays = mean(TotalPlays))
  
twentyfive_btn <- twentyfive_plays |> filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference") |>  group_by(TeamFull) |> summarise(total_plays = sum(TotalPlays), avg_plays = mean(TotalPlays))




Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data=twentyfour_btn, 
    aes( 
      x=reorder (TeamFull, avg_plays), 
        weight=avg_plays
  )
  ) +
scale_y_continuous(labels=comma) + 
  labs(
    title="2024 Big Ten Avg Plays by Team", 
    x="School", 
    y="Plays Per Game Ran"
) +
    theme_minimal() + 
  coord_flip()









I copy and pasted that code, but plugged in the 2025 data.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data=twentyfive_btn, 
    aes( 
      x=reorder (TeamFull, avg_plays), 
        weight=avg_plays
  )
  ) +
scale_y_continuous(labels=comma) + 
  labs(
    title="2025 Big Ten Avg Plays by Team", 
    x="School", 
    y="Plays Per Game Ran"
) +
    theme_minimal() + 
  coord_flip()









There are many reasons why a Big Ten offense would have a high tempo. In the case of the 2025 Indiana Hoosiers or 2024 Oregon Ducks, maybe your an effective uptempo offense who is using no-huddle to get up and down the field on opponents. Or in the case of the 2024 and 2025 leaders in plays per game, maybe your a poor football team who’s offense is constantly stuck on the field. These charts dmeonstrate that total plays are not an effective predictor of team success, although they can be an interesting indicator of your team’s style and system.

title: How does Maryland volleyball stack up to the conference’s best?
text:
First we need to load the tidyverse and our special library for waffle charts


Code
suppressMessages(library(tidyverse))
suppressMessages(library(waffle))


Then we need to load in our 2025 match data.


Code
twofive_matches <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dwillis/NCAAWomensVolleyballData/main/data/ncaa_womens_volleyball_matchstats_2025.csv")


Rows: 4878 Columns: 38
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (4): team, opponent, home_away, result
dbl  (33): ncaa_id, team_score, opponent_score, s, kills, errors, total_atta...
date  (1): date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Now we will isolate the data to find the statistics we’re looking for for the Terps.


Code
md <- twofive_matches |> filter(team == "Maryland") |> group_by(team) |> summarise(totalkills = sum(kills), totalblocks = sum(block_solos + (block_assists/2)), totalaces = sum(aces), totalopperrors = sum(defensive_errors))


Now we’re going to use the waffle function to create our code to visualize the distribution of Maryland’s points.


Code
md <- c("Blocks"=115, "Kills"=525, "Aces"=72, "Opponent Errors" = 257)
  waffle(
        md/3, 
        rows = 10, 
        title="Maryland Points Breakdown", 
        xlab="1 square = 1 point", 
        colors = c("black", "red", "gold","grey")
)









Now I’m going to compare the Terps to one of the conference’s best teams in Nebraska.


Code
neb <- twofive_matches |> filter(team == "Nebraska") |> group_by(team) |> summarise(totalkills = sum(kills), totalblocks = sum(block_solos + (block_assists/2)), totalaces = sum(aces), totalopperrors = sum(defensive_errors))




Code
neb <- c("Kills" = 777, "Blocks" = 141, "Aces" = 60, "Opponent Errors" = 325)
  waffle(
        neb/3, 
        rows = 10, 
        title="Nebraska Points Breakdown", 
        xlab="1 square = 1 point", 
        colors = c("Blue", "Green", "Pink","Orange")
)











Code
md <- c("Kills"=525, "Blocks"=115, "Aces"=72, "Opponent Errors" = 257, 334)
iron(
  waffle(
    md/3, 
    rows = 10, 
    title = "Maryland Points Breakdown", 
    xlab = "1 square = 1 point", 
    colors = c("black", "red", "gold", "grey", "white")
  ),
  waffle(
    neb/3, 
    rows = 10, 
    title = "Nebraska Points Breakdown", 
    xlab = "1 square = 1 point", 
    colors = c("blue", "green", "pink", "orange" )
  )
)









Nebraska generally has over 300 more points than the Terps which tracks given that they win a lot more than them. The most stark difference in their distribution is that almost 5% more of Nebraska’s points come from kills than the Terps. Maryland seems to be lagging behind the conference’s elite in it’s ability to finish points the simnple way. Interestingly, Maryland has more total aces than Nebraska on the year, so the Terps have been relying on the strong serves of players like Lily Wagner to create advantages. The teams have a similar proportion of blocks, while Nebraska generates more opponent errors proportionally suggesting Maryland needs to do a better job of extending rallies to and making their opponent hit returns.

title: How bad was Mike Locksley’s Third Down decision against Illinois
text:
Many Maryland fans were outraged at Mike Locksley’s passive decision to run the ball late in Maryland football’s game against Illinois eventually leading to them tying the game with a field goal and then losing. How common is a run play in those situations though? Lets find out. To start I’m going to load my required library and college football pxp data for the last five years.


Code
suppressMessages(library(tidyverse))
suppressMessages(library(cfbfastR))




Code
logs <- load_cfb_pbp(season = 2021:2025)


Now we’ll isolate the third and six plays.


Code
third_and_six <- logs |> filter(down == 3, distance == 6) 

third_and_six_summary <- third_and_six |> group_by(play_type) |> summarise(total_plays=n()) 


According to the data Locksley’s decision was passive, but not entirely uncommon, over the last five seasons team have ran the ball 3,362 times on third and six, good for just over 20% of the third and six plays.


Code
third_and_six_summary |>  summarise(overall_sum = sum(total_plays), rush_pct = 3362/overall_sum)


# A tibble: 1 × 2
  overall_sum rush_pct
        <int>    <dbl>
1       16447    0.204


Teams have actually found decent success doing this gaining an average of just under 5.7 yards, although this does include quarter back runs and improvised scrambles.


Code
third_and_six |> filter(play_type == "Rush") |> summarise(avg_yds_gained = mean(yards_gained))


# A tibble: 1 × 1
  avg_yds_gained
           <dbl>
1           5.69


Which teams have ran the most in this situation in a single season? To the suprise of no CFB fans the top spot belongs to Navy who ran it 16 times in third and six situations in 2022. No Maryland teams are in the upper echelon of third and six runs in a single season.


Code
third_and_six_runs <- third_and_six |> filter(play_type == "Rush")

third_and_six_runs <- third_and_six_runs |>
  group_by(season, team) |>
  summarise(total_runs = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(total_runs))


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'season'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


Now lets compare Locksley’s Terps teams to the rest of the nation.


Code
mdthird_and_six <- logs |> filter(team == "Maryland", down == 3, distance == 6) 

mdthird_and_six_summary <- mdthird_and_six |> group_by(play_type) |> summarise(total_plays=n()) 


Out of 71 third and six situations Maryland has been in, they have ran the ball 15 times, good for 21.1% of the time and just a tick above the national average.


Code
mdthird_and_six_summary |>  summarise(overall_sum = sum(total_plays), rush_pct = 15/overall_sum)


# A tibble: 1 × 2
  overall_sum rush_pct
        <int>    <dbl>
1          71    0.211


Now a fact that might suprise many Terps fans, they’ve achieved some decent success on these run plays, gaining an average of six yards per play getting them exactly to the line to the gain.


Code
mdthird_and_six |> filter(play_type == "Rush") |> summarise(avg_yds_gained = mean(yards_gained))


# A tibble: 1 × 1
  avg_yds_gained
           <dbl>
1              6


Lastly, I wanted to take a look at if Locksley and the Terps tendencies have changed in these situations over the years. The answer is slightly. 2022 was an all-time high with five run plays on third and six, since then it’s been on the way down with just 2 in 2024 and one so far in 2025.


Code
mdthird_and_six_runs <- mdthird_and_six |> filter(play_type == "Rush")

md_third_and_six_runs <- mdthird_and_six_runs |>
  group_by(season, team) |>
  summarise(total_runs = n()) |>
  arrange(desc(total_runs))


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'season'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.




Code
third_and_six_runs <- third_and_six_runs |> group_by(season) |> summarise(mean_rushes = mean(total_runs))




Code
comparison <- left_join(md_third_and_six_runs, third_and_six_runs, by = "season")


comparison_long <- comparison |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols = c(total_runs, mean_rushes),
    names_to = "type",
    values_to = "runs"
  )




Code
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(comparison_long, aes(x = factor(season), y = runs, fill = type)) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge(width = 0.7)) +
  labs(
    title = "How often does Maryland run on third and six vs the field",
    x = "Season",
    y = "Number of Runs",
    fill = ""
  ) +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c("total_runs" = "#D50032", "mean_rushes" = "gray70"),
    labels = c ("National Average", "Maryland")
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14)









This visualization shows how the Terps have stacked up to the national average of third and six run plays in any given season. In three out of the five most recent seasons they’ve been below it with 2022 being the biggest outlier.
While the data doesn’t take into account time, score, and game script, from a statistical standpoint Maryland isn’t a particularly passive team compared to the rest of the country. Beyond that Locksley’s best argument for the run call is that on average running the ball in that situation has meant the Terps moved the chains. Still, in recent years Maryland has seemed to favor dropping back to pass and ran it less than everyone else in the country.

title: The 2021 season: the nadir of rushing relevance in college football
11 seasons into Maryland’s transition to Big Ten football
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.1     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(ggrepel)




Code
logs <- read_csv("https://thescoop.org/sports-data-files/footballlogs1525.csv")


Rows: 17240 Columns: 80
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (11): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, Bowl.x, TeamURL, Outcome, Bowl.y,...
dbl  (65): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...
lgl   (3): Score, TeamScore, OpponentScore
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
mdlogs <- logs |> 
  filter(Team == "Maryland")




Code
mdwinlosslogs <- mdlogs |> 
  mutate(
    wins = case_when(
      grepl("W", Outcome) ~ 1, 
      grepl("L", Outcome) ~ 0)
)




Code
mdwinlosslogs |> 
  group_by(Season) |> 
  summarise(
    TotalPlays = sum(TotalPlays), 
    TotalYards = sum(TotalYds), 
    DefensivePlays = sum(DefTotalPlays), 
    DefensiveYards = sum(DefTotalYds), 
    TotalWins = sum(wins)) |> 
  mutate(
    OffensiveYPP = TotalYards/TotalPlays, 
    DefensiveYPP = DefensiveYards/DefensivePlays) -> ypp


In July 2014, Maryland made the choice to move all of its sports from it’s historic position in the ACC to the Big Ten. There can be no debate that the school made the right decision financially, but it moved the football team into a much tougher conference where they’ve struggled to compete. How has maryland fared compared to the national averages in yards gained and allowed per game across its first 11 seasons?


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=ypp, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, size=TotalWins), 
    color="grey", 
    alpha=.5) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 5.562701) +
      geom_vline(xintercept = 5.811255) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=ypp, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, label=Season)
  )  + labs(title="Maryland's mixed bag Big Ten era", subtitle="The Terps have had more below average seasons then not since joining the conference*", caption="*2025 season in progress  Source: NCAA | By Max Schaeffer")  + theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    )









Maryland’s had two seasons where it was on the positive side of the national average both offensively and defensively. One being the 2020 season where the Terps played just five games and won 2 and the other being an eight win season in 2023. When the Terps made three straight bowl games, from 2021-2023 they were above average in at least one category all three years.
Their most populated quadrant is the one they will be most anxious to avoid with five seasons of below average production on both sides of the ball. While he has become a recent target of Maryland fan’s ire amid it’s four game losing streak, Mike Locksley is only responsible for two of Maryland’s worst five seasons.
The Terps current season has been one of ups and downs, but the (extremely young) defense has been surprisingly the team’s strength. Locksley and offensive coordinator Pep Hamilton’s inability to generate any sort of rushing attack has their offensive production at one of it’s worst rates ever through eight games.
The Terps have four more games against including two against fellwo conference bottom dwellers Michigan State and Rutgers to try and move their offensive production to the rights side of the Y-Axis and salvage what could be year seven in the disaster zone if things don’t go to plan.

title: Which NFL offenses have changed the most in 2025?
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.1     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(nflreadr)
library(ggalt)


Registered S3 methods overwritten by 'ggalt':
  method                  from   
  grobHeight.absoluteGrob ggplot2
  grobWidth.absoluteGrob  ggplot2
  grobX.absoluteGrob      ggplot2
  grobY.absoluteGrob      ggplot2




Code
pxp2022 <- load_pbp(seasons = c(2022))
pxp2025 <- load_pbp(seasons = c(2025))


mia_redzoneweekthree <- pxp2022 |> 
  filter(posteam == "MIA", yardline_100 < 21, week < 4, play_type %in% c('run', 'pass' ))

mia_redzoneweekthree <- mia_redzoneweekthree |> summarise (
  total_epa = sum(epa)
)




Code
mia_redzone <- pxp2022 |> 
  filter(posteam == "MIA", yardline_100 < 21, play_type %in% c('run', 'pass' ))

mia_redzone <- mia_redzone |> summarise (
  total_epa = sum(epa))


First we had to fact-check FiveThirtyEight’s article by reverse engineering their code to find out if they had the correct total plays in the red zone for Miami and total epa on said plays. Other then them having an incorrect column title of “plays per game” instead of “total plays” I came up with the same data that they had. Next I had to begin looking at the data for all teams:


Code
redzoneweekthree <- pxp2025 |> 
  filter( yardline_100 < 21, week < 4, play_type %in% c('run', 'pass' ))

redzoneweekthreesummary <- redzoneweekthree |> group_by(posteam) |> 
  summarise(
    totalplayswk3 = n(),
    totalepawk3 = sum(epa),
    epaperplaywk3 = totalepawk3/totalplayswk3
  )




Code
redzone25 <- pxp2025 |> 
  filter(yardline_100 < 21, play_type %in% c('run', 'pass' ))

redzone25summary <- redzone25 |> group_by(posteam) |> 
  summarise(
    totalplays = n(),
    totalepa = sum(epa),
    epaperplaytotal = totalepa/totalplays
  )




Code
dumbell_combine <- redzoneweekthreesummary |> inner_join(redzone25summary, join_by(posteam))


Once I had properly created two separate data charts with epa/play for every team I had to join them, so I could use that singular data frame for a dumbell plot. I used some of the code I used for the dumbell plot from my project as a framework and then put together the data and labels I needed. One tricky part was finding the right sizing since you need 32 teams on the Y-axis.


Code
ggplot(dumbell_combine) + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    aes(y=reorder(posteam, epaperplaytotal) , x=epaperplaywk3, xend=epaperplaytotal),
    linewidth = 2,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "green",
    colour_xend = "blue") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "EPA per play changes since week 3",
    subtitle = "Green = EPA through first 3 weeks | Blue = Full season EPA",
    x = "Epa/Play Change",
    y = "Team"
  ) 


Warning in geom_dumbbell(aes(y = reorder(posteam, epaperplaytotal), x =
epaperplaywk3, : Ignoring unknown parameters: `linewidth`


Warning: Using the `size` aesthetic with geom_segment was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use the `linewidth` aesthetic instead.









The chart shows some interesting trends for teams who have had changes. I ordered the chart by who has the most epa/play currently and the Giants despite having the largest increase remain worst in the league in epa/play. This begs the question: just how historically terrible was the first three weeks of the Russell Wilson Giants offense. Houston has a similar story. Some teams have regressed like my Steelers and most significantly the Dolphins who led the league in epa/play for the first three weeks, before coming down closer to league average.
Mike McDaniel’s creative motion offense allows them to come up with play designs in the offseason that make them more unpredictable in the early weeks. However, as soon as Tua sees pressure the offensive gameplan crumbles and we’ve seen more meltdown games from him and the offense in recent weeks like that against the Browns.

title: Maryland men’s soccer claims Big Ten regular season title on strength of its wingers
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.1     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(janitor)



Attaching package: 'janitor'

The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    chisq.test, fisher.test


Code
library(ggrepel)




Code
set.seed(1234)
players <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dwillis/NCAAWomensSoccerData/refs/heads/main/data/ncaa_mens_soccer_playerstats_2025.csv") 


Rows: 5250 Columns: 24
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (7): team, full_name, roster_name, first_name, last_name, yr, pos
dbl (16): season, team_id, number, ht, gp, gs, goals, assists, sh_att, so_g,...
lgl  (1): corners

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.




Code
activeplayers <- players |> filter(so_g > 5, goals > 1) 

activeplayers <- activeplayers |> mutate (goal_pct = goals/so_g)

activeplayers$yr <- factor(activeplayers$yr, 
                           levels = c("Fr", "So", "Jr", "Sr"))

md <- activeplayers |> filter(team_id == "392")

psu <- activeplayers |> filter(team_id == "540")


Maryland men’s soccer has returned to dominance in 2025, posting an undefeated regular season and the regular season Big Ten Title with a record of 12-0-3. The Terps have largely leaned on a stonewall defense, goalkeeper Laurin Mack combined with a centerback pairing of Lasse Kelp and Tristen Rose have the Terps allowing under a goal per game through the regular season.
Offensive prowess has come from the wings though where Sadam Masereka and Stephane Njike have excelled combining for 16 of the teams 40 goals this year. Both have also shown themselves to be clinical hitting the back of the net on over 35% of their shots on target.


Code
ggplot() + geom_quasirandom(data=activeplayers, aes(x=yr, y=goal_pct), color="grey")  +
    geom_quasirandom(
    data=md, 
    aes(x=yr, y=goal_pct), color="red") +
    geom_quasirandom(
    data=psu, 
    aes(x=yr, y=goal_pct), color="blue") +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=md, 
    aes(x=yr, y=goal_pct, label=full_name)) + 
  labs(
    title = "Masereka and Njike stand out against other players their age",
    subtitle = "Qualifying players have taken at least five shots on target and scored at least twice\nBlue = Penn State Players (The Nittany Lions finished last in the Big Ten)",
    x = "Year of School",
    y = "Conversion Percentage",
    caption = "Data source: Derek Willis Chart: Max Schaeffer"
  )









Maryland got offensvie contributions from other places too. Center forwards Rocket Ritarita and Joseph Picotto tagged on two goals a piece, but both converted at a rate under 30%, lower than what Cirovski would hope for from traditional No. 9s. Maryland also got boosts from senior left back Luca Costabile and midfielder Albi Ndrenika, totaling four seniors who put up multiple goals on over five chances.
The Terps will continue to rely heavily on Njike and Masereka to create offense in the Big Ten and then NCAA tournament, but if teams dedicate extra focus to them defensively, they will have to look to create for some players with post-season experience like Costabile and Ndrenika. Whether those experienced player’s finshing can be relied upon, could be the difference between a run to the Final Four in North Carolina or a dissapointing early upset for Cirovski’s Maryland.

Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.1     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors




Code
logs <- read_csv("https://www.thescoop.org/sports-data-files/footballlogs25.csv")


Rows: 1255 Columns: 77
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (9): Location, Opponent, Result, OT, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Conferenc...
dbl  (64): Rk, Gtm, Points, PointsOpp, PassCmp, PassAtt, PassPct, PassYds, P...

Code
btn <- logs |> filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference")




Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=btn, aes(x=Date, y=RushYA, group=Team)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 12))











Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=btn, aes(x=Date, y=RushYA, group=Team)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 12)) +
  facet_wrap(~Team)











Code
btn_avg <- btn|> summarise(avg_RushYA = mean(RushYA)) |> pull(avg_RushYA)

national_avg <- logs|> summarise(avg_RushYA = mean(RushYA)) |> pull(avg_RushYA)




Code
ggplot() +   
  geom_hline(yintercept=btn_avg, color="blue") +
  geom_hline(yintercept=national_avg, color="red") +
  geom_line(data=btn, aes(x=Date, y=RushYA, group=Team)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 12)) +
  facet_wrap(~Team) 









Football in the Big Ten has traditionally been known for it’s midwest less glamorous ground-and-pound defense heavy style. This year, the conference’s elite have mostly upheld that reputation, with top three teams: Indiana, Ohio State and USC featuring dangerous run games each posting over the conference average 4.46 yards per carry in a majority of their games this year. The conference’s average is slightly higher than the national average of 4.28 yards per carry.
While the conference’s elite have hung their hat on running the ball, the conference’s bottomdwellers have also offered some terrible running performances. Wisconsin, Rutgers, and Maryland have all spent most of their time under both the national and conference average. Maryland has one major outlier, in the second best yards per attempt game of the season against the Rutgers Scarlet Knights. The best game of the season? Oregon against the Scarlet Knights, who’s run defense is more like a charity for backfields that need a confidence boost.
